Last week, Senator Bernie Sanders argued during a Senate hearing that one of President Trump’s nominees should be disqualified from public service because of his faith as a Christian.   In doing so, Senator Sanders questioned the fundamental beliefs Christians around the world have held for centuries, and attempted to establish a litmus test that would disqualify any person with similar beliefs from serving in government.    Although this has been mostly overlooked by the media, every American, regardless of their religious beliefs, should be outraged.   Article VI of the United States Constitution maintains that “no religious test shall ever be required as a qualification to any Office or public Trust under the United States.” Furthermore, the First Amendment guarantees the right of all citizens to exercise their religious beliefs freely and peacefully, stating that “Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof.”   Implying that the government should have a religious litmus test that may disqualify a person from service in the government is dangerously close to overstepping this constitutional boundary and represents a slippery slope that threatens the rights of every American. The freedom of religion extends to people of all faiths and we must all vigilantly protect it as such.   This dangerous and intolerant attempt at political correctness by Senator Sanders should be admonished by all Americans.

I rise today in strong support of the CHAMPIONING HEALTHY KIDS Act, which extends the State Children’s Health Insurance Program (SCHIP) for another five years. Last year, nearly 100,000 Hoosier kids received health insurance thanks to this critical program.

Americans are a compassionate people, and federal social safety net programs that ensure those who are too young, too old, or too ill have access to important services, like health care, reflect that compassion. Congress created the State Children’s Health Insurance Program (SCHIP) in 1997 as a partnership with the states to ensure the healthcare needs of lower-income kids were met, and it is important that we continue to ensure that those needs are met going forward.
